chapter_2_The_java_util_function_Package

Class Consumers

  • java.lang.Object
    • chapter_2_The_java_util_function_Package.Recipe_2_1_Consumers

  • public class Consumers
extends java.lang.Object

    (2.1.) Consumers


    1. TO DO

      - write lambda expressions that implement Consumer

    2. HOW

      - implement the void accept(T t) method using a lambda expression or a method reference

    3. EQ.

      • printTheElementsOfACollection() - print the elements of a collection
      • usePeek() - use peek method

    An implementation of a Consumer is the Iterable.forEach(Consumer) method which passes each element of an iterable collection to the consumer argument.
    Primitive variations and two-argument version:
    • IntConsumer - void accept (int x)
    • DoubleConsumer - void accept (double x)
    • LongConsumer - void accept (long x)
    • BiConsumer - void accept (T t, U u)
      Variations of this are ObjIntConsumer (takes a generic and an int), ObjDoubleConsumer and ObjLongConsumer.

    Consumers are expected to operate via side effects.
    Other uses of the Consumer interface:
    • Optional.ifPresent(Consumer<? super T> consumer) - if a value is present, invoke the specified consumer. Otherwise do nothing.
    • Stream.forEach(Consumer<? super T> action) - performs an action for each element of the stream. Similar to this is Stream.forEachOrdered(Consumer), accessing elements in encounter order
    • Stream.peek(Consumer<? super T> action) - returns a stream with the same elements as the existing stream, first performing the given action.

      • printTheElementsOfACollection

        protected static void printTheElementsOfACollection()
        ◊◊◊ Print the Elements of a Collection ◊◊◊ 
             List<String> strings = Arrays.asList("this", "is", "a", "list", "of", "Strings");

     // anonymous inner class implementation
     strings.forEach(new Consumer<String>() {
        @Override
        public void accept(String s) {
            System.out.println(s);
        }
     });

     // expression lambda
     strings.forEach(s -> System.out.println(s));

     // method reference
     strings.forEach(System.out::println);

      • usePeek

        protected static void usePeek()
        ◊◊◊ Use peek method ◊◊◊ 
             List<String> collected = Stream.of("aa", "bb", "cc")
                .peek(System.out::println).collect(Collectors.toList());
